text:
Hey Adeena!

I'm glad you got something out of my essay above hehe and you are very welcome. It's my pleasure to support you in any way I can!

You talk about wanting to help people less fortunate than others, as well as a desire to go into teaching. Both very admirable. Have you heard of TeachFirst?? It's a charity that help train teachers to work in state-schools and help disadvantaged children. They are a highly reputable company and it's very respected to work for them. You should deffo check out their website because it's exactly as you say...you could go and study a science-based degree and then teach science within a school. You know there are certain tax incentives to teach a science-based subject too :wink:
Let me grab the website for you actually!

Here is a bit of info about their teacher training programme >> <https://www.teachfirst.org.uk/training-programme>
and this is their eligibility requirements to join their teaching prorgamme >> <https://www.teachfirst.org.uk/knowledge-base/eligibility/eligibility-requirements>

attachments.title: Training Programme | Teach First
attachments.text: Make a difference every day on the largest teacher training and leadership programme in the UK.

attachments.title: Eligibility requirements | Teach First
attachments.text: Find out what qualifications and criteria you need to meet to be eligible for our Training Programme.

text: And of course it means that when you study your degree you are still free to change your mind i.e. if you no longer wanted to be a teacher then at least you have a respected degree under your belt that can take you many places
My cousin is a teacher by the way, so if you had any questions I can ask her for you
She works in a primary school and has just been promoted to Assistant Head Teacher and has her own classroom etc
